Review: The Great Gatsby

17/05/2013

Any joys to be found in Baz Luhrmann's adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel are entirely superficial.

Image by

By James Bithell

Director: Baz Luhrmann Starring: Leonardo DiCaprio, Carey Mulligan, Tobey Maguire Length: 143 minutes Rating: Baz Luhrmann's The Great Gatsby is a film that will undoubtedly get a lot of earnest English Lit. students' backs up. But it was obvious, even before the film's release, that this was always going to be the case. The apoplectic social media reaction following the release of the lurid trailer made it apparent that, for some, the very concept of the director of Moulin Rouge! being allowed to adapt the Great American Novel, with Jay-Z handling soundtrack duties, was something approaching sacrilege. In spite of this, what many failed to remember is that film adaptations of literary classics too afraid to take liberties with the source material are invariably disappointing: Jack Clayton's soporific 1974 version of Fitzgerald's classic is testament to this. If ever an on-screen incarnation of Gatsby were to truly succeed, bold direction would be required. And whatever you think of Luhrmann's previous work, you could certainly never accuse him of not being bold. Despite its inherent silliness, Luhrmann's previous literary adaption, 1996's Romeo + Juliet was an audacious, brilliantly trashy, piece of filmmaking. The arch irreverence that Luhrmann brought to that film is once again on display in the opening act of The Great Gatsby. Luhrmann's has always been criticized for placing style ahead substance and, true to form, the film's opening cuts straight to the surface but, to be fair to him, that surface is pretty fantastic. For the film's opening his signature maximalist visual style serves the material perfectly: the elements of the trailer that people took most issue with- the garish visuals, the frenetic camerawork, the anachronistic soundtrack- all work to bring the roaring twenties to pulsating life. Well, his gaudy, hyper-stylized conception of them at least. 1920s New York is rendered as a heightened CGI art-deco unreality and you can't help but be impressed by the scale of it all. The party setpieces documenting the bacchanalian excess of the Jazz Age, that take place at Jay Gatsby's mansion, are impressive for their sheer ridiculousness: watching revelers popping champagne bottles and dancing the Charleston, while confetti and tinsel falls all round, to the sounds of 'A Little Party Never Killed Nobody' by Fergie is effortlessly engaging. Gatsby's entrance, a low-key scene in the novel, is gloriously overblown here. As he turns to announce "I'm Gatsby," Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue plays and fireworks erupt in the background. It's all very funny and, whether or not it is intensionally so, is never a distinction worth worrying about too much. The film then runs into the obstacle of having to actually tell a story. Luhrmann treats narrative as a chore; something he is obliged to do so that he has something to tack onto the party sequences so he can present something that resembles a film, as opposed to an extended music video. Oddly, Luhrmann and his writing partner (Craig Pearce) pay the source material too much and too little respect simultaneously. Sometimes, they treat Fitzgerald's prose like hallowed scripture: lines from the novel are narrated as the text is superimposed onto the screen. They are at pains to show they think Fitzgerald's words are important, but never actually respect them enough to actually interpret them. Not once do they mine the novel's fertile ambiguities. Any form of interpretation would have sufficed really. It needn't have been particularly incisive but, on the evidence of this film, you imagine that if Luhrmann were faced with the standard A-Level exam question of "What does The Great Gatsby have to say about the American Dream?", he'd be stumped. All the important plot points and motifs are presented but to no discernible end. Instead, The Great Gatsby is recast as a great romance, redolent of something from a Nicholas Sparks film, and misses the point of Fitzgerald's novel spectacularly. The real tragedy was not, as Luhrmann sees it, that Gatsby and Daisy were not able to be together, but rather, the realization that he had fallen for the wrong girl. This is why it is so incongruous that the line: "they were careless people, Tom and Daisy- they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money," is narrated verbatim. It doesn't appear that Luhrmann genuinely believes it: Daisy (Carey Mulligan) is presented as a wholly sympathetic romantic heroine throughout. For the most part, the characters are reduced to ciphers, reciting lines, often lifted directly from the novel, but are devoid of any real feeling or consequence. This is a great shame because Leonardo DiCaprio assumes the role of Gatsby in a way that you can't imagine any of his contemporaries could, but he is swimming against the tide: he is a first rate actor stranded in a second rate film. Elsewhere, Joel Edgerton give a one-note performance as Tom Buchanan, Daisy's bullying, perfidious husband, but captures none of his underlying vulnerability and Tobey Maguire has always been an insipid screen presence but never more so than here, as Nick Carraway, the vaguely creepy, outside-inside narrator. So, The Great Gatsby is a failure and not even an admirable one. The subtlety and nuance packed into every line of Fitzgerald's prose is suffocated beneath an avalanche of glitter and any joys to be had are purely superficial. Baz Luhrmann does show that he knows how to throw a party. Unfortunately, he has failed to see grasp that, in Fitzgerald's novel, the dull headache and dry mouth of the morning after the night before; the insistent pangs of regret and, ultimately, the realization of the vapidity of it all, were always of far greater significance.
